title: 103_s1208
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government units before the National Park Service took over preservation responsibilities. Financial constraints have hindered the Federal Government from meeting the capital needs of these historic sites. The Federal Government has been unable to meet the capital needs of historic buildings in Philadelphia due to financial constraints. Minting a United States coin is proposed as a way to commemorate these sites and help fund their maintenance and preservation for future generations. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue $1 silver coins with specific specifications and designs emblematic of national shrines. These coins will be legal tender and the silver for minting them will come from stockpiles established under a specific act. The Secretary will obtain silver for $1 silver coins from stockpiles under a specific act. The design will be chosen in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one mint facility for up to a year after enactment, with sales authorized. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted. A surcharge of $7 per coin is required for all sales. Procurement regulations are waived for goods and services needed for this Act. Surcharge distribution is also addressed. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

    The Secretary will collect surcharges from coin sales, with 50% going to the Treasury to reduce the national debt and 50% to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for various preservation efforts.

SEC. 10. AUDITS.

    The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditures related to the surcharge distribution. SEC. 10. AUDITS.

The Comptroller General of the United States can examine the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's records related to surcharge expenditures. 

SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND.

Coins issued under this Act are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund provisions. 

SEC. 12. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 11. The coins issued under this Act are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government and require adequate security for payment before issuing coins.
